xxl.core.relational.cursors

Class Projection

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
      • xxl.core.relational.cursors.Projection
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<Tuple>, Cursor<Tuple>, MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>

    public class Projection
extends SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
implements MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>>
    Straight forward implementation of the operator projection.

    In earlier versions of XXL it was possible to hand over a string array to the constructor of the operators instead of an array of indices. To get this functionality, use ResultSets.getColumnIndices(ResultSet, String[]).

    The example in the main method wraps an iteration containing arrays of five int values [i, i+1, i+2, i+3, i+4] to a metadata cursor using Cursors.wrapToMetaDataCursor(java.util.Iterator, Object). Then, the column becomes projected and the cursor is printed on System.out. The interesting call is: 

       cursor = new Projection(
       cursor,
       ArrayTuple.FACTORY_METHOD,
       1,
       3,
       5
   );

    • Constructor Detail

      • Projection

        public Projection(MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> cursor,
                  Function<Object,? extends Tuple> tupleFactory,
                  Projection<Object> projection)
        Creates a new instance of projection. The projection of the tuples derived from the underlying cursor is done by the given projection-function.
        Parameters:
        cursor - the input metadata cursor delivering the input elements.
        tupleFactory - a function that maps a list of objects (column values) to a new tuple. Classes implementing the Tuple interface should provide factory methods for this task. If null is passed, a factory method producing array-tuples is used.
        projection - a function that maps an object array to a projected object array.

      • Projection

        public Projection(MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<Object,Object>> cursor,
                  Function<Object,? extends Tuple> tupleFactory,
                  int... columns)
        Creates a new instance of projection. The tuples derived from the underlying metadata cursor are projected onto the specified columns.
        Parameters:
        cursor - the input metadata cursor delivering the input elements.
        tupleFactory - a function that maps a list of objects (column values) to a new tuple. Classes implementing the Tuple interface should provide factory methods for this task. If null is passed, a factory method producing array-tuples is used.
        columns - an array of column numbers the tuples are projected onto.

    • Method Detail

      • peek

        public Tuple peek()
           throws IllegalStateException,
                  NoSuchElementException,
                  UnsupportedOperationException
        Shows the next element in the iteration without proceeding the iteration (optional operation). After calling peek the returned element is still the cursor's next one such that a call to next would be the only way to proceed the iteration. But be aware that an implementation of this method uses a kind of buffer-strategy, therefore it is possible that the returned element will be removed from the underlying iteration, e.g., the caller can use an instance of a cursor depending on an iterator, so the next element returned by a call to peek will be removed from the underlying iterator which does not support the peek operation and therefore the iterator has to be wrapped and buffered.

        Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors. After calling the peek method a call to next is strongly recommended.

        Specified by:
        peek in interface Cursor<Tuple>
        Overrides:
        peek in class SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
        NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the cursor.

      • next

        public Tuple next()
           throws IllegalStateException,
                  NoSuchElementException
        Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.
        Specified by:
        next in interface Iterator<Tuple>
        Specified by:
        next in interface Cursor<Tuple>
        Overrides:
        next in class SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the cursor is already closed when this method is called.
        NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

      • getMetaData
